The '''royal sign-manual''' is the [[signature]] of the sovereign, by the affixing of which the monarch expresses his or her pleasure either by order, commission, or warrant. A sign-manual warrant may be either an executive act (for example, an appointment to an office), or an authority for affixing the [[Great Seal of the Realm|Great Seal]] of the pertinent [[realm]]. The sign-manual is also used to give power to make and ratify treaties.<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911 |wstitle=Sign-Manual, Royal |volume=25 |page=81 |inline=1}}</ref> ''Sign manual'', with or without hyphen, is an old term for a handwritten signature in general. It is also referred to as ''sign manual and signet''.
==Commonwealth realms== [[File:Australia Act 1986.jpg|thumb|The [[Australia Act 1986]] bearing the royal sign-manual of [[Elizabeth II]]]] [[File:Autograph of Elizabeth I of England.svg|thumb|The royal sign-manual of [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]]]] [[File:George III signature.jpg|thumb|The royal sign-manual of [[George III of the United Kingdom|King George III]]]] [[File:Edwardsig.svg|thumb|The signature of King [[Edward VIII]] as King-Emperor]] ===Composition=== The royal sign-manual usually consists of the sovereign's [[regnal name]] (without number, if otherwise used), followed by the letter ''R'' for ''Rex'' (king) or ''Regina'' (queen). Thus, the signs-manual of both [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] and [[Elizabeth II]] read ''Elizabeth R''. When the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British monarch]] was also [[Emperor of India|Emperor or Empress of India]], the sign manual ended with ''R I'', for ''Rex [[Imperator]] or Regina Imperatrix'' ([[king-emperor|king-emperor or queen-empress]]).
When the future [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]], then the [[Prince of Wales]], [[Regency era|became regent]] on behalf of his incapacitated father, [[George III]], the [[Regency Act 1811]] expressly directed that the prince should sign "George P R", the initials standing for ''Princeps Regens'' meaning ''[[prince regent]]''.
===Uses=== Some [[letters patent]] are not signed by the monarch in person. Instead, the monarch signs a warrant authorizing the preparation of the letters patent (traditionally written in ceremonial calligraphy on [[vellum]]) and approving the draft text of the letters patent. Then, once the letters patent are prepared, they are sealed with the Great Seal without the need for the signature of the monarch, because royal authority for issuing the letters patent had already been given by means of the warrant. Those letters patent finish with the words "By warrant under the King/Queen's Sign Manual," to signify that they do not bear the sign-manual themselves, having already been approved by warrant signed by the sovereign.
Other letters patent, due to the nature of their contents (such as those that authorise the expenditure of money, or those that signify [[Royal Assent]] to [[Act of Parliament|Acts of Parliament]]), require the royal sign-manual to be affixed directly to them. Such letters patent contain, at the bottom, the words: "By the King/Queen Him/Herself, Signed with His/Her own hand." The royal sign-manual is usually placed by the sovereign at the top of the document. These papers usually must be countersigned by a [[Secretary of State (United Kingdom)|principal secretary of state]] or other responsible minister.<ref name=EB1911/>
In some cases, the use of the sign-manual has been dispensed with and a stamp affixed ''in lieu'' thereof, as in the case of [[George IV of the United Kingdom|George IV]], whose bodily infirmity made the act of signing difficult and painful during the last weeks of his life. The [[Royal Signature by Commission Act 1830]] ([[List of Acts of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, 1820â€“39#11 Geo. 4 & 1 Will. 4|11 Geo. IV & 1 Will. IV c. 23]]) was passed providing that a stamp might be affixed ''in lieu'' of the sign-manual, but the sovereign had to express his consent to each separate use of the stamp, the stamped document being attested by a confidential servant and several officers of State.<ref name=EB1911/><ref>{{Citation| last=Anson| first=William Reynell| title=Law and Custom of the Constitution| place=| publisher=General Books| date=1907| volume=II| edition=i| page=59| isbn=978-0-217-08715-5}}</ref>
==Kingdom of the Netherlands== [[File:Signature_of_Willem-Alexander.png|thumb|The signature of King [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands]]]] According to article 47<ref>https://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0001840/2017-11-17#Hoofdstuk2_Paragraaf2_Artikel47</ref> of the [[constitution of the Netherlands]], all [[Act of Parliament|Acts of Parliament]] and [[Royal Decree]]s have to be signed by the King and by one or more [[Minister (government)|Ministers]] or [[Secretary of state|State Secretaries]] (called a [[Countersign (legal)|countersign]]). No one else can sign on behalf of the King. When he is abroad, he can sign using a [[tablet computer]], but will still sign the paper original upon his return.<ref>https://www.koninklijkhuis.nl/onderwerpen/rol-van-het-staatshoofd/vraag-en-antwoord/hoe-ondertekent-de-koning-wetten-en-koninklijke-besluiten-als-hij-in-het-buitenland-is</ref>
